item.title: Travel Map
item.description: I want to see as much of the world as possible while I can. The map I’m making here will serve as a reminder of the memories I made around the world, and as motivation to go out and see the rest. To make the map I used R and ggplot. I relied heavily on The Lucid Manager’s post in which he creates his own version. First loading all the necessary libraries

item.title: My Journey to Cornell
item.description: My career so far has been a delightfully eclectic adventure. In this post I provide a brief summary of my experiences and how they led me to Cornell. The stated purpose of this post is to introduce myself to readers. The real purpose is to help me sort through my own life and organize my thoughts. 1. University of Winnipeg 2012 - 2016 I completed my undergraduate degree in Psychology at the University of Winnipeg.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: About Me
item.description: I am a PhD student in Cornell’s Policy Analysis and Management program. I received my MSc from the London School of Economics and my undergradute degree from the University of Winnipeg. Before starting at Cornell, I spent two years working in people analytics at Multi Health Systems Inc. I have experience in quantitative and experimental social science, product development, and business strategy. I am passionate about a lot of things.

item.title: extra_text
item.description: Through policy, governments set the rules of the game that all firms and workers play. I want to change the rules so that the game gives fairer rewards and everyone has a more equal chance at success. Why do people flock to major cities despite ever-rising costs of living? Why is competition declining across industries? How did elite education become a necessary and sufficient condition for economic success? Answering these questions requires accessing new kinds of data, revealing hidden social networks, identifying causal mechanisms, and understanding economic incentives.
